intro: Commiphora rivae, commonly known as the African myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing trees. The plant is characterized by its rough, fissured bark and small, leathery leaves. It produces a resinous sap that has been traditionally used for medicinal and aromatic purposes. The botanical features of Commiphora rivae make it an important species in both ecological and cultural contexts.
